subject: Re: [junit] What happened to getName()?
msgSnippet: On Sat, May 9, 2009 at 4:18 PM, Mark Thornton ... I experimented for some time with having a test class that inherited from the class under test, as a cheap
messageBody:
On Sat, May 9, 2009 at 4:18 PM, Mark Thornton
<mark.p.thornton@...> wrote:
>> The
>> tradeoff was that if we dropped getName(), programmers would be free to
>> subclass from anything for their test classes. I haven't subsequently used
>> this freedom to any good effect, but it seemed like a good idea at the
>> time.
>
> Does anyone have an example where this has been used to good effect?
>
> Regards,
> Mark Thornton

I experimented for some time with having a test class that inherited
from the class under test, as a cheap way to override some methods,
but didn't get enough value for the design cost to continue doing
that.

_Requiring_ test classes to extend a common base class had design
issues. One of the biggest was that inheritance became the favorite
extension mechanism of JUnit extensions. If you want to test GWT,
inherit from GwtTestCase. If you want to test with mocks, inherit
from MockObjectTestCase. If you want to test GWT with mocks... ack.*

JUnit 4.0 got half-way to fixing this, by dropping the required
inheritance. I believe 4.7 will finish the job, by allowing a lot of
the standard extensions to use Interceptors, which are just fields.
It's much easier to add a field to a class than to insert an
additional superclass.

I hadn't realized it, but if someone will raise a feature request for
a CurrentTestName interceptor, I'd happily put it in for the next
snapshot release.

David Saff

* I'm picking on two tools I'm familiar with, and I'm not claiming
there's not already better ways to do this.
